tit.e: Ukontaku (an black engraved print as a feather)
tit.cmt: 単語の訳を追加しました
tit.e: Ukontaku (an black engraved print as a feather)

sen.j: 烏金拓（うこんたく、うきんたく）は烏の羽根のように真っ黒にとった拓本のこと。
sen.e: Ukontaku (also called Ukintaku) refers to a black engraved print as a crow feather.
Ukontaku (also called Ukintaku) refers to a engraved print which is as black as a crow feather.
Ukontaku (also called Ukintaku) refers to a engraved print which is as black as a crow feather.

sen.j: 対して「蝉翼拓」（せんよくたく）は蝉の羽根のように薄くとったものをいう。
sen.e: On the contrary, Senyokutaku refers to a light one as a cicada wing.
On the contrary, 'Senyokutaku' refers to a light one as a cicada wing.
On the contrary, 'Senyokutaku' refers to a light one as a cicada wing.

sen.j: もともと中国で拓本が生まれたのは、碑文を写し取るためだったので比較的濃く採るのを基本としていた。
sen.e: Since an engraved print was originally born in China to copy down an inscription on a stone monument, rather dark rubbing was principle.
Since an engraved print was originally born in China to copy down an inscription on a stone monument, basically print was relatively-dark.
Since an engraved print was originally born in China to copy down an inscription on a stone monument, basically print was relatively-dark.

sen.j: その後書道のテキスト（碑帖）として有名な碑、特に文が有名であったり、書家が有名なものが手本として使われるようになる。
sen.e: Later, famous monuments, especially when the text or writer was famous, were used as copybooks of calligraphy for good examples.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Later, famous monuments, especially ones whose text or writer was famous, were used as copybooks of calligraphy for good examples.
Later, famous monuments, especially ones whose text or writer was famous, were used as copybooks of calligraphy for good examples.

sen.j: すると、黒白がはっきりしている方が役に立つため、中国の拓本はほとんどが真っ黒に近いものになった。
sen.e: In that case, it was more useful when the contrast was high, so most engraved prints in China became almost jet black.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In that case, it was more useful when the contrast was high, so most engraved prints in China became almost jet black.
In that case, it was more useful when the contrast was high, so most engraved prints in China became almost jet black.

sen.j: 清朝になって白い紙（桃花紙）が出てくると、油煙墨を使ってピカピカになるほど上墨した拓本が生まれた。
sen.e: In the time of the Qing dynasty, when white paper was invented, the engraved print, rubbed by ink stick made from lamp soot until it became shiny, was born.
In the time of the Qing dynasty, when white paper was invented, the engraved print, rubbed by ink stick made from lamp soot until it became shiny, was born.
In the time of the Qing dynasty, when white paper was invented, the engraved print, rubbed by ink stick made from lamp soot until it became shiny, was born.
This is Ukontaku.
This is Ukontaku.
This is Ukontaku.

sen.j: この真っ黒にとる拓本はどうしても紙を抜けて対象物に墨を少し移してしまう。
sen.e: This engraved print, rubbed until it becomes jet black, inevitably stains the object with ink through the paper.
This engraved print, rubbed until it becomes jet black, inevitably stains the object with a little ink through the paper.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れに対応しました。
sen.e: This engraved print, rubbed until it becomes jet black, inevitably stains the object with a little ink through the paper.

sen.j: 度重なれば対象物は真っ黒になってしまい、中国の多くの碑はこのため汚れている。
sen.e: When repeated, the object becomes dark, which has made most monuments in China stained.
Repeated prints make the object jet black, and most of the monuments in China are stained for this reason.
Repeated prints make the object jet black, and most of the monuments in China are stained for this reason.

sen.j: 今日では文化財保護の立場から、烏金拓は推奨されていない。
sen.e: Today, from a standpoint of cultural property protection, Ukontaku is not recommended.
Today, from a standpoint of cultural property protection, Ukontaku is not recommended.
Today, from a standpoint of cultural property protection, Ukontaku is not recommended.
